content.description:
Currently the hardest sport climb in DTC. Impressive grey monster of a route on a huge, perfect limestone "belly". Powerful climbing with two fun crux moves leads to amazing thin climbing in the upper part of the route. There's little respite from the pump till the very top.

Named after Red Deer climber Lucas Chabot who tragically died during the climbing competition in Nov 2019.



Walk 30m up the hill from "start of the line" till you see a fixed chain leading to the good stance under the limestone "belly'. Pull on the chain past 3 bolts over the rotten rock to the start.

12 bolts, chained belay station.

From the top of the chain climb the right line. Powerful overhanging moves lead to a good rest on a big flake. The crux is right where the angle lessens. From there it's thin and sustained climbing to the anchors. Great fun!


Bolted, anchors on top

Stick clip the second bolt (perma draw).

The first line to fall on the upper wall, this line heads up/right of the white streak. Scramble up onto a ledge (stick clip from here, you cannot reach either of the first two bolts when you're climbing!) to start with a mean layback on dreadful rock (the rock is solid after the first couple of moves). Head up the weakness in the rock that can very loosely be described as an open book feature passing several bolts to a no hands rest on a ledge; now the real climb starts!

Several difficult sections await you, as well as several good rests separating the cruxy sections. The climbing is technical, footwork intensive, and slightly overhung- save some gas for clipping the anchor!

Named for Konstantin Stoletov and his growing family. 

From the overhang where the trail deposits you, head to your left, up the hill ~50 m. Look for the first white streak, with a perma-draw ~5 m off the deck. 
13 bolts, rap ring

Scramble up to the starting ledge to clip a low first bolt- choose your holds wisely. Follow the line of tightly spaced bolts through relatively easy, but strange climbing for ~8 m to a comfortable no hands rest just below the prominent ledge. Traverse left along the ledge, and clip the first chain perma-draw overhead. Gain the ledge, and an awkward no-hands rest. Chalk up, breathe, go.

Pull a straight forward, easy boulder through the steepest part of the overhang; much of the difficulty comes from clipping the second chain perma-draw mid-sequence. Trend slightly right (following the bolt line) into very sustained, elegant face climbing on phenomenal rock! While no individual bolt to bolt sequence touches V4, the sections stack up on you!

Climb right of the last bolt to a good rest, then straight up to the chains from your rest stance. It is possible to go left at about the same difficulty, but two consecutive holds are a slightly suspect. 



From The Overhang, head left (south) up the hill ~45 m. Look for the the two chain perma-draws to the right of the prominent white streak. Follow the bolt-line down/right, look for the low bolt on the starting ledge. 

10 draws, 2 perma's, 2 bolt anchor

climbs.name: Ronnie Takes a Walk in Heaven

content.description:
Start as for "Rusalka", pulling the improbable but easy boulder over a bulge to a rest stance. From here, clip the bolt immediately right of the jug and break right through a short section of classic resistance climbing. Traverse up and across the white streak to another rest stance, and then take your airy walk* in heaven along the ledge. As the ledge ends, head up for one more bolt and then the chains! 

Named by Brad Mix for the late Ronnie Mix.

*Not a walk, but easy! Easiest to have someone follow it to retrieve gear. Semi-hanging belay at the top is also possible. 



From The Overhang area, head left (south) up the hill until you see a fixed line (~60 m). Scramble up to the tree'd ledge, this line starts ~2 m before the end (climbers right) of the ledge. Shares the first 4 bolts with "Rusalka" then heads up and right. Aim for the highest ledge on the wall, cross 2 bolt lines on your way to the chains. 

12 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

Pull off the deck following easy territory to the 3rd bolt. Boulder over the bulge (easy, ~.10+) to a good rest, and then launch into technical, slightly overhung face until you gain a ledge. Clip up and continue over easy terrain to a rest stance at the last bolt.

Climb to the hidden chains straight above the last bolt, keeping it cool through a difficult sequence on pinches and side pulls until you can reach any of the "Thank God" holds above the anchor bolts!

From the overhang where the trail deposits you, head to your left and up the hill ~50 m. This line climbs the black-ish streak left of the big white streak (Little Luc). Start from the tree'd ledge- scramble up the mossy slope ~5 m after Little Luc to gain the ledge.
9 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

Step off the ledge and pull through ~5 m of easy slab to the business of the climb. Cruise up the elegant face on open hand holds breaking left just below the highest ledge to aim for the alcove (heading slightly right to the white streak/ledge is "Violent and Young").

Take your time and get everything back at the hands free rest (and also long draw the bolt that's at your chest). Then, walk your feet and hands pulling a tricky boulder to gain an absolute bucket (at the last bolt). Rest again, and the pull an unlikely series of moves on decent holds to a comfortable stance for clipping the chains!

This is an alternate exit to the original line, "Violent and Young". Named after Kendra Young/ the Vallis Alps song, "Young".



From "The Overhang", head up the hill ~50 m. Climber, take the fixed line up to the ledge, belayer, set up just below and right of the ledge (clear of the scree rock fall while your climber sorts their life). Clip the bolt to the right of the ledge before you start. Follow the bolt line and aim for the alcove (slightly left) when the bolt line branches.

12 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

Climbs just left of the prominent white streak. Step off the "Rusalka" ledge and pull through a meter of garbage rock (basically just pick a foot hold that won't snap and go!). Head up easy terrain on heinously sharp holds to where the wall kicks back to dead vertical. Thin, techy climbing leads you to a rest. Clip the "Whipping Bolt" (a.k.a. the lone 12 mm bolt on the line) and race the pump through the slight overhang to the chains, merging with "Little Luc" at the last bolt and sharing the anchors. 

Named for Kendra Young. 



From The Overhang, head left/up the hill ~60 m to the static line. Scramble up to the ledge, and look for the bolt line at the very end of the ledge (climbers right). Set up your belayer below the ledge, reach out and clip the first bolt before leaving the deck. 

12 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.

Highly featured, compact rock. Climbing is generally thin, technical, and slightly overhanging interspersed with good rests. Several lines start off a tree'd ledge (walk until you find the fixed line). This sector gets filtered morning sun. The upper wall can be absolutely scorching while the incredibly sharp rock at the bottom is ice cold. 

Stick clipping is highly recommended as you have to pass a short band of low quality rock which guards a superb headwall. Stick clipping required for "Little Luc". 

Currently one open project: "Big Lue", bolted in honour of the late Lucas Chabot. Look for the fixed chain that leads up to a bolted belay stance on the far right of the wall (towards The Overhang). ~20 m, 10 bolts. A couple of nasty boulder problems and very sustained thin climbing after. 5.13-.14 range.
